issues.title: Control and Management Plane Attacks and Mitigations
issues.author: talmi
issues.body:
Generally speaking, most of the "generic" security considerations for the control plane and management plane apply to SRv6 as well.
Below is a list of issues taken from SRv6-related documents that may be worth mentioning. Some of these issues are SRv6-specific, while others are generic (not SRv6-specific), and the latter are marked below with a [generic] tag.

Control plane attacks
=====================

[draft-ietf-spring-srv6-security]
- an attacker can advertise SIDs in order to manipulate the SR policies used in the network
- [generic] Known IPv6 control plane attacks (e.g., overclaiming) are applicable to SRv6 as well.

[draft-ietf-pce-segment-routing-policy-cp]
- provide an eavesdropper with additional information about the SR Policy

[RFC9259]
- The O-flag may be set by an attacking node attempting a denial-of-service attack on the OAM process at the segment endpoint node.
- An on-path attacker able to observe this OAM channel could conduct traffic analysis, or potentially eavesdropping (depending on the OAM configuration), of this telemetry for the entire SR domain from such a vantage point.
- Once an HMAC is generated for a segment list with the O-flag set, it can be used for an arbitrary amount of traffic using that segment list with the O-flag set.

[RFC8476]
- Advertisement of an incorrect MSD value may have negative consequences.  If the value is smaller than supported, path computation may fail to compute a viable path.  If the value is larger than supported, an attempt to instantiate a path that can't be supported by the head-end (the node performing the SID imposition) may occur.


Control plane mitigation methods
================================

[draft-ietf-idr-bgp-ls-sr-policy]
- the SR Policy information advertised via BGP sessions is limited to nodes and/or controllers/applications in a secure manner within this trusted SR domain.
- [generic] isolation of BGP-LS sessions from BGP sessions for other address-families

[draft-ietf-pce-segment-routing-policy-cp]
- [generic] As per [RFC8231], it is RECOMMENDED that these PCEP extensions can only be activated on authenticated and encrypted sessions across PCEs and PCCs belonging to the same administrative authority, using Transport Layer Security (TLS) [RFC8253] as per the recommendations and best current practices in [RFC9325].

[RFC9513]
- [generic] [RFC7166] describes an alternative and improved authentication mechanism to IPsec for OSPFv3.  The use of authentication is RECOMMENDED for OSPFv3 deployment.

[RFC9259]
- An implementation correctly implementing the rate limiting described in Section 2.1.1 is not susceptible to that denial-of-service attack.


Management plane attacks
===================================
[draft-ietf-lsr-isis-srv6-yang]
[draft-ietf-lsr-ospf-srv6-yang]
- [generic] There are a number of data nodes defined in this YANG module that are writable/creatable/deletable (i.e., config true, which is the default).  These data nodes may be considered sensitive or vulnerable in some network environments.  Write operations (e.g., edit-config) to these data nodes without proper protection can have a negative effect on network operations.

Management plane mitigation methods
===================================

[draft-ietf-lsr-isis-srv6-yang]
[draft-ietf-lsr-ospf-srv6-yang]
- [generic] The lowest NETCONF layer is the secure transport layer, and the mandatory-to-implement secure transport is Secure Shell (SSH) [RFC6242].  The lowest RESTCONF layer is HTTPS, and the mandatory-to-implement secure transport is TLS [RFC8446].
- [generic] The Network Configuration Access Control Model (NACM) [RFC8341] provides the means to restrict access for particular NETCONF or RESTCONF users to a pre-configured subset of all available NETCONF or RESTCONF protocol operations and content.

pulls.title: Modification to the threat model
pulls.author: fernandogont
pulls.body:
I've reorganized/re-ordered the text, and have included a new section. This is the rationale:

* STRIDE is a model for finding threats. So it should guide us in that regard (note that RFC3552 is rather dated).

* All threats in S-T-R-I-D-E are really relevant. The new section that I've added tries to elaborate on that.

* This new section also calls out the issue that protection for tampering/spoofing relies an a feature (HMAC TLV) which is really optional.

* I wouldn't focus on "packet-based attacks" for the threat model. -- yes, that can help the thought process. But when doing threat model ing, there more to analyze of SRV6 as a "system". And this things become more evident if one follows a structured model such as STRIDE.

* In this edit, I've removed the dsicussion on the "CIA" triad. Mostly because is basic security terminology, but also because just the "CIA" triad does not help much to find threats as (otoh) e.g. STRIDE.

* There were a number of things that were flagged as "out of scope". I believe unless we have a very good documented rationale for that, we should cover all angles.

pulls.title: Various updates based on PR 24
pulls.author: talmi
pulls.body:
A set of updates related to threats and impacts, based on PR 24 (https://github.com/buraglio/draft-bdmgct-spring-srv6-security/pull/24). Following a discussion of the authors, the text is adapted to be based on ANSI impact components rather than STRIDE components.

The text of this PR is based on the text of PR 24.

The main aspects of this PR:
- A new section about impacts which is based on the six ANSI components, incorporating the aspects from PR 24.
- The HMAC aspects of PR 24 were moved to the mitigation section.
- CIA was removed from the threat model section.
- Packet based attack abstractions were moved from the threat model section to the attack section.
- Attack subsection heading fixed in order to be consistent.

reviews.author: fernandogont
reviews.body: Hi @talmi ! I've reviewed your proposed changes. Thoughts?

comments.body: These references should be clarified. RFC3552 and RFC9416 are both part of BCP72. As such, they are IETF's guidelines on how to write security considerations sections and do threat modeling, so to speak (e.g., RFC9416 even introduces requirements to spec writers).  Regarding [RFC9055] and [RFC7384], I'd reference them in the specific sections where they are applied, with the spe ific issue being discussed in such RFCs.
Note: HMAC is also meant to protect against packet forging.

I believe there are a number of aspects that need to be addressed here:

1. Things like STRIDE, ANSI-sec, or the like, may be approaches for conducting threat modeling -- i.e., finding possible threats. However, they don't really classify the impact, because the impact may be affected by a number of aspects, including mitigating factors or techniques.

2. The method/technique one uses simply has the goal of finding threats. As such, i wouldn't flag any threats as "out of scope" -- they actually aren't. If anything, we might be unable to find any. 
3. Rather than listing the "threats" in ANSI-sec, I would probably add a top level "threats" section, and then add one level-2 section for each of the threts, where we can elaborate how each of "unauthorized access", "masquerade" (etc) could be launched/implemented in a SRV6 domain.
i.e., rather than focus on the model in ANSI-sec, just I'd just make use of it. -- and if we were to find a threat that doesn;t fit cleanly in the taxonomy in ANSI-sec,  nevertheless add it as a level-2 section (child of top level "Threats" section), together with the other ones. -- IOW, any threat-modeling framework or methodology are simply tools to find threats, as opposed to e.g., an exhaustive/specific taxonomy for threats.

pulls.title: Threat section updated

pulls.body:
Based on comments from reviews, the main changes are:

- Discussion about cryptographic mechanism / HMAC is moved to the HMAC subsection in the mitigation section.

pulls.title: Updates to the introduction
pulls.author: talmi
pulls.body:
Based on the following comments from Alvaro:

...
137        *  SRv6 makes use of the SRH which is a new type of Routing
Extension
138           Header.  Some of the security considerations of the SRH are
139           discussed in [RFC5095] and [RFC8754].

[] The SRH is specified in RFC8754.  To be strict, RFC5095 doesn't talk about the SRH.  RFC8754 already refers to RFC5095 in its Security Considerations.

141        *  SRv6 consists of using the SRH on the IPv6 dataplane, and
142           therefore known security considerations of IPv6 [RFC9099] are
143           applicable to SRv6 as well.

[] Please also point to the Security Considerations in rfc8200.

pulls.title: Updates to the mitigation section
pulls.author: talmi
pulls.body:
Two main updates based on review:
- Moved the discussion about trusted domains and filtering from the threat model section to this section.
- Moved the discussion about internal attacker with access to crypto keys from the threat model section to this section (HMAC subsection).

- Various small re-phrasing updates.

- Updated on-path and off-path terminology in light of the distinction above. As a reference, on/off path are discussed in the context of control plane attacks in RFC 7835 and in RFC 6952 as well.
